This question seems to reappear with differing values of the percent increase of radius or diameter. Maybe it is time to solve it in general for a p% increase in radius or diameter. Here, r = radius. To convert to diameter one merely substitutes d/2 = r. Start with the area of the reference circle having radius r, called area 1. area1 = Pi r^2 Compute the area of a different size circle with radius increased by +/- p %. Expressed as a fraction, the increased radius is r2 = r * (1 + p/100). area2 = Pi ((1 +p/ 100)* r)^2 = (1 +p/ 100)^2 (Pi r^2) = area1 * (1 +p/ 100)^2 Compute the percent increase (decrease if p < 0) and call it pinc. Multiply the fractional answer by 100 to convert back to percent. pinc [p_] = 100 (area2 - area1) / area1 = 2 p + p^2/100 Evaluate pinc[p] for p = +15%. pinc[15] = 32.25% as shown by two earlier answers, and illustrated by the dashed lines on the Graph below.  The function, pinc[p], works for positive or negative p indicating radius increase or decrease. It is plotted above for +/- 100% change in radius. A little thought will reveal that a 100% decrease in radius results in a point, not a circle, so that limiting value is not a realistic value for p.
